Bangor is a small coastal city in

, and although it does not have an abundance of attractions, it is a picturesque place offering views over the Menai Strait (especially attractive at sun-set), and also serves as a convenient base for visiting the nearby
. The city is also a popular place to spend the night for travellers leaving for

ferry. 

With a population of only around 14,000, Bangor is one of the UK's smallest cities. Bangor is however a University town, so there may be a few more facilities than expected for such a small place.

Around half of the people in the city can speak Welsh, but if you took away all of the students in the University, this figure would be much higher.
Bangor lies on the North Wales Coastal Line, and can be reached from either the direction of

, for those traveling from the mainland. Bangor is on the Holyhead → Chester track, and can be reached from either with trains running roughly every hour.
Bangor can also be reached the following ways:

value: → Bangor - about 2 hours travelling time. £18.10 for standard day ticket.
→ Bangor - roughly every hour, taking about four hours. £96.50 for a standard open single, £62.90 for a saver single (available most days). Booking in advance may get you a ticket for £51.
→ Bangor direct - three times a day. Takes just over 3 hours, but same price as above.

Bangor is just off the intersection of A5 and A55 between

.
Bangor is directly on the A5, which runs directly from London to Holyhead making it easily accessible from the capital city of England. This 250 mile journey takes roughly

.
From the north west of England, Bangor can easily be reached on the coastal road A55, which provides a nice safe journey on a road which serves all of the North coast of Wales. The journey takes as little as an hour and is about 65 miles (105 km).
Bangor is also served by the A487 from the west coast of Wales, from
Students visiting or moving to Bangor with a lot of luggage may find it safest to travel by coach.

value: content=Advance booking is essential to guarantee a seat. Disabled Persons Travel Helpline: +44 121 423 8479, textphone: +44 121 455 0086.
content=The quaint fishing harbour and Victorian Pier.

content=A neo-Norman Victorian Castle that contains a collection of "Norman" style furniture and old masters' paintings. Has a National Trust shop, a doll museum, two galleries and an industrial railway museum.
content=A 6th Century cathedral with attractive architecture. The focal point of the city.
content=Tells the story of the people of Bangor and Gwynedd over previous centuries.
content=Bangor City Football Club's home ground, located near the City center. A good place to go on match days to soak the atmosphere and to meet real Bangor locals.
content=Information for the entire north of Wales, tips and directions for the best days out.
address=Powis Hall and Prichard-Jones Hall, Main Arts Building, College Road

content=Regular concerts of classical music during term time, usually on Thursday and Saturday evenings. Perfomers include professional orchestras, chamber ensembles and soloists, and there are also concerts of electroacoustic music and regular performances by the University's own choirs and orchestras.

Welsh lamb and beef feature prominently as does freshly caught fish such as salmon, brown trout, white crab and lobster. Vegetarian preferences are also well catered for with organic fruit and vegetable producers in the area.
Some of the local eateries include:

value: content=Vegetarian restaurant, but not strictly for vegetarians. Pleasant cafe with surfwear shop attached. Can be easily missed on the high street, as it is down a small uninviting alleyway, but don't be put off.

content=Typical food menu and drink service. Music is now played (sometimes loudly), but family-friendly atmosphere. Food varies in quality and is not a home-made meal, typical from a high-street brand chain. Can provide the venue, but not the atmosphere. If you're looking for a good insight into Bangor culture, this will more remind you of a small bar in any city or town.

content=A very smart and elegant little restaurant that is a diamond in the rough. The food is fantastic and great value for money. A student favorite for its cheap lunches to remind them what nutrition actually is!
directions=at the front of Kellett travel

content=A small coffee shop, serves a variety of sandwiches, wraps, paninis and jacket potatoes, as well as homemade pies, burgers and weekly specials that change every week. Includes a wide range of homemade cakes and cupcakes.

There are more, and they're small private places with varied food and menus. It's worth asking a local!

value: content=Quaint cafe located on Waterloo Hill, which serves lovely tapas and other lunchtime dishes, as well as a variety of homemade cakes.

value: content=Fine drinks and fine food, definitely worth the money.
directions=Farrar Rd, then left for High street

content=
Relaxed atmosphere, delicious food, cool venue for parties, Love Bangor 10% and 15% discounts. Ideal spot for the start of a good night out or in Bangor.
directions=Towards the station on the high street

content=A friendly, cosy traditional pub. Great menu, all cooked from scratch, no microwaving here! Reasonable drink prices, and offers on house vodka, whiskey. Round of Jaegerbombs only £10 (for 6 shots and red bull) The best in Bangor!!

content=A traditional, ideally situated pub in the busy student sector, offering lunchtime snacks and main meals. Selection of local and established real ales, themed evenings and weekly quiz on Sundays.

" because of it's unusual yellow colored facade, this pub provides a great atmosphere for students to lie about, eat, drink, play pool, watch silly programs on TV, sing on the karaoke, or just take advantage of cheap beer. Great music and great food. Wifi hotspot.

content=Traditional Welsh pub where the staff are friendly, but sometimes the atmosphere might not be very welcoming towards the English (I - being VERY English DO NOT agree with this comment - they are VERY friendly towards the English!). Current and former Welsh-speaking student favorite, as well as being very popular with Bangor locals.
", this small Irish-themed bar is popular with all and makes such a stamp on visitors that they make sure to return whenever nearby.

Currently, the Students' Union has no venue, as it was demolished, along with the cinema and theatre, Theatr Gwynedd. They are due to be replaced by a complex called Pontio.

value: content=Peep is a lively night out occasionally supported by some of the top DJs in the UK. Student night is a great laugh and appears on every Wednesday during term time. Be safe here on weekends though, this is outside student territory and locals frequent this club often. However, this provides a good mix of people and can still be a great night out. More recently there are some good rock/metal nights here in the week and also the occasional band night.
directions=About 3 miles from Bangor just off the A55 Tal-y-Bont intersection

content=Hendre is Victorian Grade II listed stone farm building that has been converted to provide a venue of real character for weddings and music events. A favourite venue for local bands, DJs and promoters of world music. It does not provide accommodation.
address=University of Wales Bangor, Ffriddoedd Building, Victoria Drive.
content=Accommodation in student halls of residence - seasonal only.
content=Small, friendly bed and breakfast with 7 bedrooms and 4 ensuite. Facilities include: parking, ensuite, easy access, no smoking.
content=A nice hotel with restaurant and bar. Great for families. Pet friendly. 22 well equipped rooms (18 en-suite).
content=Located in the center of town.
content=Small, friendly bed and breakfast with 3 bedrooms situated overlooking Hirael Bay harbour. Ideal for visiting university and local attractions. Facilities include: parking, easy access.
price=£50 per night or £270 for the week
content=A two-star touring caravan and camping site, with water and shower facilities, and a few nice cottages with self-catering facilities, washing machines, etc. Pet friendly.
name=Tyn Rhos Country House Hotel Bangor
address=Ty’n Rhos, Seion, Llanddeiniolen, CAERNARFON, Snowdonia,LL55 3AE
directions=Short drive from the main city, in the countryside

content=Has superb gardens. There is a large choice of individually decorated rooms and the establishment. It also has its own restaurant, with lounge, bar, main restaurant or conservatory areas, which serves delicious and visually beautiful food sourced locally.
